Dialogue.Stage Direction: To a background of loud rumbling, the squaddies are chatting.

Dialogue.Line: Squad! 'Shun! As you were! 'Shun! Stand at ease! Don't move.
Doctor Williams. The argh. Oh. Argh.
Greg? Greg? Greg!
What's up? I was disposing of that thing's body.
I just heard something from the intercom.
Not a chance. They're all done for in there.
You come and listen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But the speaker is just buzzing.

Dialogue.Line: I did hear something. STAHLMAN 2 [OC]: Argh. Oh, oh.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stewart, the Doctor and Shaw enter.

Dialogue.Line: We've just heard something from the drill head.
That's impossible. They must all be dead in there.
I tell you we heard something. STAHLMAN 2 [OC]: Doctor Williams! Can you hear me? Raise the heat shield! Manual controls are jammed with the heat.
The Director. STAHLMAN 2 [OC]: Can you hear me, Doctor Williams? Let us, let us out! Argh.
It is the Director! We've got to do what he says and let him out of there.
You mustn't!
But he's alive.
No! Whatever you do, don't raise that heat shield.
If the Director's found a solution, then we need him out here. Now stand back, Doctor.
He must have unlocked the manuals. The controls are working.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The blast door opens part way, then a green hairy figure pushes it up to the top.

Dialogue.Line: Director!
No! Don't go anywhere near him. Don't go near him.
But he needs help!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The figure takes off its environment suit hood. Stahlman 2 is fully changed into a green hairy monster. He summons the others out of the drill head. Meanwhile, Benton enters Central Control.

Dialogue.Line: Why don't they attack?
They're acclimatising themselves. They don't want to get too far away from the heat.
Let's get out of here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The humans make a dash, but the Greens cut them off and corral them.

Dialogue.Line: The other way!
Now they've covered both exits.
We'll make a break for your office.
Benton, get out!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Too late. Benton is grabbed by the Greens and dragged towards Stahlman.

Dialogue.Line: Please, no! No, no! No, no, no, no, no!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stahlman strokes his hand over Benton's face, and Benton collapses, screaming. The Doctor opens a hatch in the computer console and pulls out a red wire. The blast door closes. The Greens rush over to it.

Dialogue.Line: Into the office!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Greg runs to Benton.

Dialogue.Line: Leave him be! There's nothing you can do! Come on, hurry!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor slams the door in Green 40653's face. Benton writhes around on the floor, rapidly transforming into another hairy Green.

Dialogue.Line: Well, we shouldn't have just left Benton! You don't mind sacrificing your men, do you, Brigade Leader?
Believe me, Mister Sutton, there was nothing we could have done.
Well not now, there isn't. He's probably been killed by those things!
Worse than that, he'll have become one of them. The heat will accelerate the process.
Well, why did you cut them off from the drill head?
To keep them away from the heat. The hotter it is, the stronger they grow.
Well, if it gets any hotter in here, they won't have to attack. We'll just shrivel up.
Well, Doctor, it doesn't look as though your space craft is going to be much good to anybody now.
Space craft?
What are they talking about?
The Doctor has some sort of device that could get him out of here.
Only the Doctor, of course. Not the rest of us.
He says he comes from a parallel world.
Look, will somebody tell me what's going on?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Across the dimensions, Gold is reading the Financial Times whilst being chauffeured back to the complex.

Dialogue.Line: Where are we, Patterson? I don't recognise this.
Different route, sir. Trying to avoid the traffic.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Gold tries to use the car phone.

Dialogue.Line: What's the matter with this thing?
No idea, sir. It was working on the way up.
It took me a day's hard talking to convince the Minister, now I can't even get in touch with the complex.
Are they going to slow down the drilling, sir?
They're going to suspend it, pending a full review of the project. Where the devil are we? It looks like the middle of nowhere. All right, Patterson, what's going on?
I'm sorry, sir. I don't understand.
(Sharply.) Answer me, please.
Orders, sir.
From whom? Professor Stahlman, wasn't it.
Yes sir.
Was I ever supposed to get back from the Ministry?
Not if you were successful, sir. I was to drive as far off the route as I could and stage a breakdown.
The man's raving mad.
He threatened to have me sacked, sir.
Well, you realise now that I have the Minister's full authority behind me.
Yes, sir.
All right. If you can break all records getting back to the complex, I might just forget about all this.
Thank you, sir, I'll be very grateful.
So you should be. Now put your foot down.
Sir, I'd, er, I'd like you to know that I objected to the order, sir.
Keep your eyes on the road! Look out!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Oncoming headlights dazzle Patterson. There is a screech of rubber on tarmac.
The Doctor pulls Greg back.

Dialogue.Line: No, no! No, don't touch it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor lets off a fire extinguisher through the broken glass.

Dialogue.Line: I don't think they'll be back for a while. They'll wait till the temperature rises.
How long have we got?
I should say all of ten minutes.
You said you had a plan just now. What is it?
Well, if we're going to get power to the Tardis console, we'll have to connect it up to the nuclear reactor.
That's if there's any power left.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor holds his handkerchief up in front of the air conditioning grille. It moves.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing?
Well, the air conditioning's still working, so power's still getting through.
Only the bare minimum. The reactor must still be working off robot control.
Can you boost the output?
Well, in an emergency, the master switch automatically shuts down the reactor banks.
But it can be re-set?
It would take time. And after that I'd still have to get to the main switch room at the reactor.
The master switch is in Central Control. How do we get through that lot?
Well, we've still got a weapon to use against them.
You mean the pistol?
No, I don't. I mean the fire extinguisher.
You can't hold them off with that thing for very long.
If that master switch has been damaged, it'll be a long job resetting it.
Well, there are other fire extinguishers in Central Control.
If we can get to them. Wait a minute! I'm a fool. Of course! The coolant reserve. I've rigged up an emergency hose.
That's it! Well, the coolant's under pressure! It's just as cold as the CO2 in the fire extinguishers.
Doctor, you've got a monster sized fire extinguisher just waiting for you in there.
Splendid. Well, we'll fight our way into Central Control using this. While Mister Sutton holds them off with his coolant, I'll repair the master switch.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Green tries to put its arm through the window again. Greg uses the extinguisher while the Doctor gets to the door bolt.

Dialogue.Line: Right. Now!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor opens the door, the Greens rush in only to be driven back by Greg and the CO2.
Everyone dashes over to a power cable under some flooring. Greg hands over the extinguisher to the Brigade leader.

Dialogue.Line: Hurry up, Sutton!
I'm going as fast as I can. Everything's red hot.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stahlman is creeping into the room from behind them.

Dialogue.Line: I can't breathe!
Well, stop talking so much.
Look out!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stahlman heads for the Doctor and Greg, and Stewart takes him down with the CO2 then turns back to the other Greens.

Dialogue.Line: That's enough. Don't waste it! That's enough, I said! It's Stahlman!
Is he dead?
No, I think he's just paralysed. He'll probably come to again when the temperature rises.
Petra, give me a hand here!
Sutton, get that hose going!
I can't. It's seized up!
Well, what do we do now?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor grabs a wrench from a tool box and takes it to Greg, dodging Stahlman's grasping hands.

Dialogue.Line: Right.
Brigade Leader!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stewart uses the last of his CO2 on the Greens.

Dialogue.Line: They're coming!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Greg snatches up the end of the long hose and waves it at the Greens. Coolant vapour drives them back against the wall.

Dialogue.Line: Right, off you go!
What about you?
Don't worry about me. I'll stay and repair the master switch.
Greg!
I'll stay with the Doctor.
Come on, let's get going!
Go on. I'll cover you!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stewart, Shaw and Williams run out.

Dialogue.Line: Okay, Doctor, get on with it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The whole area is red hot and looks like a furnace.

Dialogue.Line: It is hot out here.
I still find it impossible to breathe.
Well, no use hanging about.
We've got to wait for them!
We must get right away from here.
Wait for them.
They'll find us.
You go if you want to, Brigade Leader.
The heat's made a pretty good mess of this.
It's making a mess of me too,
You can always join the others outside, you know, Mister Sutton.
I think I'll hang around a bit longer. The natives are getting restless again.
Are they now?
How are you making out?
Slow but sure, Mister Sutton.
Doctor?
Mmm hmm?
When you get back to that other place.
If I get back.
How are you going to make sure they stop their drilling?
I don't know. Maybe somebody will listen to me there. Sir Keith, for instance?
But he's dead.
Here, perhaps. In the other world, maybe not.
(into phone) That's absurd! There must be some trace. People don't just vanish! Well, keep looking. Let me know when you have any news.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Benton enters.

Dialogue.Line: Excuse me, sir.
Well, where is he?
I'm sorry, sir, but he just won't come.
Sergeant, I sent you to get Professor Stahlman.
Well, that's just it, sir. Professor Stahlman won't come. He's says he's too busy to
Too busy to what, Sergeant?
He says he's too busy to waste time bandying words with a pompous military idiot, sir!
Sergeant, I want to see Professor Stahlman and I want to see him now, and I advise you not to come back without him.
Sir, if you
A chance to use your initiative, Sergeant!
Sir!
Carry him in here if you have to, but get him!
Sir!

Dialogue.Character: (Liz is turning switches, looking at the empty space where the Tardis used to be, and sighing. The doors start rattling so she rummages through her handbag for a sonic screwdriver, checks to see who is out there, and opens them. LIZ
Dialogue.Line: Won't you come in, Mister Sutton? SUTTON: Hello. Yes. How did you do t[hat? LIZ: With this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And closes the doors again.

Dialogue.Line: A useful little gadget, eh?
One of the Doctor's inventions. He used to call it the door handle.
Nice bloke, the Doctor. I miss having him around the place.
So do I. Is there anything I can do for you, Mister Sutton?
Er, well, it's, er, it's like this, I
Yes?
Well, I found myself passing this place and
So you thought you'd just take a look?
Well, yes, I thought I might get a look at that wonderful machine the Doctor was supposed to be working on.
Well, as you can see, there's nothing here.
He took it away with him, did he?
That's right.
Do you know, it's a funny thing now.
What is?
Well, I've been asking round, and nobody actually saw him go.
Didn't they?
Well, that banger he uses is not exactly inconspicuous, and he didn't say goodbye to anyone.
He didn't have very much time. He left in rather a hurry.
Well, since there's nothing here now, what are you still hanging around for?
I don't know, I suppose I'm half-hoping he'll suddenly come back.
Just like that?
He's very unpredictable.
I thought, possibly, the poor old Doctor had blown himself to smithereens and you were trying to hush it up.
Yes, well, there was a sort of an accident.
Well, there's no sign of an explosion.
No, no, not an explosion exactly, he
Well, this is a great place for disappearances, isn't it?
How do you mean?
Haven't you heard? I gather Sir Keith Gold's vanished too.
This time, Brigadier, you've really gone too far. I'm literally dragged from my work by one of your ape-like minions.
He was acting on my orders.
By what possible right can you
Professor Stahlman, I have made innumerable attempts to secure a few moments of your valuable time. You've left me no choice.
Oh, very well. I suppose I'd better humour you. What is it you want?
Sir Keith Gold has disappeared.
Has he? I thought he was in London pouring out his petty complaints to the Minister.
He left the Minister yesterday evening. He should have been back here by last night.
Well, an accident perhaps?
There's been no report of any accident on any possible route from here to London.
Well then, I imagine he's had his complaints dismissed and has taken himself off in a fit of pique. It doesn't matter. We shall do very well without him.
I've tried to contact the Minister but he isn't available. Therefore, in view of Sir Keith's anxieties about this
Sir Keith is an old woman.
I must formally request that you delay Penetration Zero until his return.
On no account, Brigadier. This project will be carried through on schedule. My schedule. When that drill penetrates the Earth's crust, you'll see that my theories were correct.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But in the alternate reality, Greg is still holding back the Greens.

Dialogue.Line: Time's running out, Doc.
That's it. I only hope it works. Shall we go, Mister Sutton?
I thought you'd never ask.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Greg uses the coolant to herd the Greens back to the passage towards the drill head.

Dialogue.Line: Right you are, Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor runs across the room and grabs two extinguishers from the wall.

Dialogue.Line: Hurry along, my dear fellow. Hurry along!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Greg puts the coolant pipe on the floor, takes an extinguisher from the Doctor and they leave. Green Stahlman stands up and follows.

Dialogue.Line: There they are!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor drives everyone there in Bessie.

Dialogue.Line: I'll check the inner corridor.
Now, Mister Sutton and I had better start work on the power connection. Will you be long, Doctor Williams?
I have to re-route the entire electrical system before I can boost the power.
Be as quick as you can.
What about the Brigade Leader and me?
Well, you'd better wait here.
Isn't there anything we can do?
No, I'm afraid not. Now, I'll need some tools and a length of heavy duty cable.
We can pick that up at the rigger's stores. You'll pass it on the way to the hut.
Right, come on, let's get on with it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The whole place shakes.

Dialogue.Line: What's happening?
It's an earthquake!
It's getting nearer!
Yes, we're sitting on a powder keg!
Right, come on!
Get a move on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Greg take an extinguisher and drive off in Bessie. Meanwhile, a Green steps out of Central Control into the open air.

Dialogue.Line: I wonder if those creatures are moving out yet?
Quite possible.
It's getting warm enough for them.
How long is all this going to take?
I don't know.
Well, can't you hurry it up, Doctor Williams?
No, not if I'm to do the job properly.
You must! We've very little time!
Brigade Leader, I'm trying very hard to carry out a complex scientific task under impossible conditions. You will not help matters by bullying me.
You are insolent, Doctor Williams.
Am I? Then it's about time that you learned that some problems just can't be solved by brute force and terror.
Better let her get on with it, Leader. We're in her hands.
We've got to the power through to the hut. It's our only chance.
But the Doctor said he can't take us with him.
Do you think he wants to help us? He's only concerned with his own safety.
I think he's telling the truth. I think he has been all along.
When the time comes, he will take us. He'll have no choice.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: One by one the Greens step out in to the 'cold' outside air.
Greg brings over th[e end of the cable.

Dialogue.Line: So that's the contraption, is it?
The console, Mister Sutton, the console.
Well, I thought it'd be a bit more impressive than that.
What did you expect? Some kind of space rocket with Batman at the controls?
And this brought you all the way here, did it?
Er, well, it wasn't exactly a journey in the accepted sense of the word. It sort of slipped me sideways into your dimension.
Will it take you back?
Theoretically, yes.
Well, is it all right?
I hope so. Now fix the connector to the cable, will you?
Right. I hate to tell you, but if we put the entire output of the nuclear reactor through this, it'll blow in the first few seconds.
A few seconds are all I need, Mister Sutton.
Are you making any progress?
I'm worried about the relay circuits. They're not functioning properly. I'm trying to rig up a bypass.
Could the reactor have packed up?
No, it's still working, but it could go at any moment.
Yes, we're well aware of that, Doctor Williams. You must hurry!
As I've already told you, Brigade Leader, I'm hurrying as fast as I can.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Another quake.

Dialogue.Line: All right, Brigade Leader, we're still here.
I don't like your tone. Those explosions are getting closer. I'm thinking about the safety of all of us.
Oh, yes, yes, of course you are.
We've all got to get out of here!
You go if you want to. I shall stay here and finish the work.
You carry on with your work!
Where's there to go?
If that spacecraft of the Doctor's works, you'll see for yourself.
You don't really think you can force him to take us? He's not the sort of man you can frighten.
Once that thing's working, we can take it over.
We don't know how to operate it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: BOOM!

Dialogue.Line: Doctor Williams can learn how to operate it. She's a scientist!
That device is beyond all our comprehension.
Then I shall have to persuade him to operate it for us.
And if he tries to go by himself?
And leaves us to die? I shall make sure that he dies first.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is working unde[rneath the console.

Dialogue.Line: If we get you back, Doctor, you'd better make darn sure they stop their drilling. I'd hate to think all this was for nothing.
Right. You can connect up the cable now.
Right. And cross our fingers and trust to luck.
We're not relying on luck, Mister Sutton, but skill.
Finished?
I think so. I just have to switch on and pre-set the power controls.
How do we know the Doctor's ready for the power?
Oh, it doesn't matter. The power won't flow until he switches on at his end.
And then we may all go up in smoke?
No, I've switched off all other circuits.
Good luck.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Williams pulls the power lever down into the red.

Dialogue.Line: Well? What's happened?
Nothing.
There must still be a fault.
So, you've been wasting our time.
Try again.
It's no use! I'll have to go through the whole wiring system all over again!
What's happened to them? They should [be back here by now.
You must try and be patient.
If those explosions reach the nuclear reactor.
Yes, I know.
That's coming from the drill-head!
The shaft must be splitting open!
Well

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stahlman has come in through the inner door.

Dialogue.Line: Get out! Get out both of you!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The women run. Brigade Leader shoots at Stahlman then follows. Outside, they all keep falling over as the ground shakes, whilst they run from Benton and another Green.

Dialogue.Line: No si[gn of them. Nothing!
Well, that appears to be that. I doubt whether they would have listened to me anyway.
They're coming! All three of them! Well done, Petra! Are you ready, Doctor?
What's the matter?
I'm sorry. I couldn't get the power through. I did all I could.
Yes, of course you did, my dear.
Well, we tried, eh, Doctor?
One can't do more than that, Mister Sutton.
Oh, very philosophical, Doctor. Thank you very much, I knew you tried. All very cosy.
Hysteria won't help us, Brigade Leader.
Nothing will help us. That bore's going to blast any minute and we'll all be roasted alive.
Look what's happening to our hard man. You were all very tough when you were backed up by a bunch of thugs. How do you like it on your own?
I warn you
You warn me? That's a laugh. You're finished, Brigade Leader. Finished!
I can still deal with you, Sutton!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stewart jabs his pistol into Greg's stomach.

Dialogue.Line: With that? Even if you had the guts, you'd only be doing me a favour.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Click. The Brigade Leader is out of bullets.

Dialogue.Line: What do you do now, slap my wrists?
I don't need a gun to finish you!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stewart grabs Greg round the throat but is easily pushed off and thumped in the gut. Greg punches the Brigade Leader around the hut.

Dialogue.Line: Listen to that! Do you want to end your lives fighting like animals?
Where's Petra?
She's gone back to the main switch room to have another try at getting the power through.
Oh, the idiot! I'd better get after her.
I'll come with you.
No, Doctor! You stay here. She might just manage it, and if she does, you need to be here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Williams is working at the control panel while Stahlman lies on the floor.

Dialogue.Line: What do you think you're doing?
I'd nearly finished the rewiring when we had to run out of here. I only need a few more minutes.
It was crazy to come back in here.
It doesn't matter. He's dead.
Well, he may not have been. What are you trying to do, commit suicide?
What does it matter? We're nearly finished anyway.
All right but get a move on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As Greg watches the door, Stahlman gets up and snarls at Williams. Greg runs over, snatches up an extinguisher and uses it on him.

Dialogue.Line: Are you all right?
I think so. That should do it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Four red lights start blinking.

Dialogue.Line: It's working!
All right, let's get back to the hut.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is lying on the floor. He is clearly back in the correct reality because the shelves are a jumbled mess of books. Liz opens the doors with her sonic screwdriver and enters.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Liz calls out across the complex.

Dialogue.Line: Sergeant! Over here, quickly!
What's the matter? It's the Doctor!
I can see that. Tell the Brigadier.
Right, Miss Shaw.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The clock reads 3:22:38 and counting.

Dialogue.Line: It's perfectly straightforward, Petra. We boost all power circuits to maximum load and that'll give us a further acceleration of three point six percent. Well, do you find some fault in my calculations?
Of course not, Professor Stahlman.
Well then, what's the matter?
We're already twelve percent over the planned acceleration. Well, another three percent'll take us well over the safety margin.
Safety margins are for cautious old women like Sir Keith. I know perfectly well what I'm doing. Pass on my instructions please.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stahlman leaves.

Dialogue.Line: You look worried.
He's ordered a further acceleration. Three point six percent.
But he can't do that!
I'm afraid he can.
We're pushing the safety limits now.
Yes, I know.
I'm going to have a word with him.
Greg, it's no use. He usually listens to me, but this time
But not any more, eh? Let's face it, Petra, he's losing his grip.
Professor Stahlman's been working on this project for years. He must know what's going on.
But he can still make mistakes, can't he? If he makes one at this stage, it could be a lulu!
Greg, let me talk to him first.
All right. You go and soften him up and I'll close in for the kill.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Petra leaves. The Brigadier enters, followed by Benton.

Dialogue.Line: Sir?
Well, Benton?
Excuse me, sir, but it's the Doctor. He's, well, he's back.
Well, where is he?
Well, he's in the hut, sir. Miss Shaw's with him.
Right, I'll come back with you now.
Right, sir.
My dear Miss Williams, much as I value your services, I must remind you that you're not in control of the

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stahlman stops, staring at nothing.

Dialogue.Line: Professor! Professor Stahlman! Are you all right? You look ill.
Yes, I have a headache, that's all.
You really ought to go to the sickbay.
I'm perfectly all right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sutton enters.

Dialogue.Line: Look, Professor Stahlman, this accelerated drilling. It just isn't on, you know.
Someone else is about to tell me how to run my own project.
Well, we should be slowing down at this stage, not forcing the pace.
The drilling will continue at the pace I decide.
Professor, you've been working on this project for years, right? What's the mad rush in the last few hours?
We must reach penetration zero at the earliest possible moment. Every second

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stahlman stops again.

Dialogue.Line: Professor? Professor? You need a rest.
I don't want to discuss the matter any further. Please carry out my instructions at once.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stahlman leaves.

Dialogue.Line: I thought you were supposed to soften him up?
He just wasn't listening. Greg, he's ill. He had some sort of attack!
Yes, I saw it. Let's face it this whole thing's getting too much for him. He's cracking up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is lying on a camp bed as Liz che[cks his heart rate.

Dialogue.Line: Heart's beating steadily.
Both of them?
Yes.
Well, what's the matter with him?
Some sort of coma.
How long before he comes out of it?
Difficult to say. Could be a few hours, a few months.
Months?
Some people never recover.
I'll send for a doctor.
I happen to be a doctor, Brigadier, remember?
Shouldn't he be in hospital?
I think it'd be very dangerous to move him at all.
What, leave him here?
Why not? It's quiet. We can keep him warm.
Miss Shaw, I really think he needs medical attention.
Brigadier, I will look after him.
If you could spare me a moment, Professor? I've been checking an emergency flange on number two output pipe.
It was repaired some time ago.
Yes, well, the man didn't do a very good job and at the rate we're drilling, that flange could blow at any moment.
Then what do you suggest?
Well, if you could slow down the drilling rate, I can get a proper job done.
Another transparent excuse for delay.
Excuse, nothing! At the speed we're drilling, we could blow this place sky high before you ever reach penetration zero.
Mister Sutton, you're here on sufferance. That being the case, I suggest
I'm here because I was sent for by Sir Keith! And believe me, working with you is no pleasure.
Then I suggest you stop interfering in matters beyond your understanding.
I'm trying to help. I am supposed to be an advisor.

Yes, one of Sir Keith's little army of experts. Well, we don't need your advice, Mister Sutton. Now that ridiculous Doctor has gone, Sir Keith himself has gone, why don't you follow their example? And then we might make some progress.
Don't worry, I'll do just that. As far as I'm concerned you can blow yourself to kingdom come!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stahlman leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Greg! You're not serious, are you?
Of course I'm serious. If I can't do anything else, at least I can save my own neck. Why don't you come with me?
You're convinced there'll be a blow up?
I'd take odds on it well?
I can't leave. You know that.
Loyal to the last, eh?
I wish you'd change your mind about leaving.
Why?
Well, if anything were to happen, I'd like to think you were here.
Just for the good of the project?
No! Not entirely. I've just got used to your being around.
Maybe I haven't been wasting my time down here after all.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An alarm goes off. Smoke and green ooze are pouring from the drill head.

Dialogue.Line: (into phone) Hello. Get me Control. Yes, I can hear the alarms. Now this is Brigadier Lethbridge Stewart.[ Now get me Control!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor's face twitches.

Dialogue.Line: Hello, Control? Lethbridge Stewart here. Now, what's happening? Yes. Yes, yes, yes, go on! How serious?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor groans. Eyes still closed, he starts talking.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor?
Number two. Number two output pipe blown.
Doctor, can you hear me?
Number two output pipe.
What did he say?
Very dangerous. Very dangerous. Number two output pipe blown.
How on earth did he know?
What?
The emergency flange on number two output pipe has blown. It's just this minute happened.
Listen.
There's only one thing, one thing to do. Reverse, reverse all systems. Reverse all systems immediately.
Reverse all systems.
Reverse all systems!
Delirious.
Yes.
He knew about the leak, almost as though he expected it.
But how could he? Look at him, he's still in a coma.
Doctor, can you hear me? Doctor? Doctor?
It's no good.
Keep an eye on him, Brigadier. I think Central Control ought to know about this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Technicians are rushing about.

Dialogue.Line: Keep calm! This is only a minor emergency. It can be contained.
Professor, stop the drill!
No, positively not.
You'd better do something, and quick, Professor, otherwise you'll bust this place wide open!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Liz enters.

Dialogue.Line: Have those riggers arrived yet?
Look, an army of riggers are not going to get you out of this one!
Oh, get back there. Go on! Get back to your posts all of you! Back to the drill head. How dare you leave bank seven. (Stahlman chases a group of technicians back into the drill head.)
Look at him! He's out of his mind! He's not even trying to think of a solution!
Is there one?
What would happen if you reversed all the systems?
What?
Reversed everything.
Well, it's not such a crazy idea. It's been done before.
With an oil shaft?
Yes, in Arabia. You push all the coolant down the output pipes and draw up the debris from the bottom of the shaft in the input pipes.
Reverse the vortex?
Yes.
It's a possibility, theoretically.
Professor Stahlman would never permit it!
Just do it.
Why not? What about it, Petra?
Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor continues to twitch while the alarm sounds, then relaxes as it shuts off.

Dialogue.Line: Well, I reckon it's working.
Seems to be.
That was a brilliant idea of yours.
Oh, it wasn't my idea.
Then who? No, don't tell me. The Doctor. I heard he was back.
That's right, the Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is far less smoke coming out of the drill head.

Dialogue.Line: I gave no such orders.
No, Professor Stahlman, I did.
Even you, Petra.
Doctor[, are you all right?
(waking) Liz? It is Liz.
How are you, Doctor?
Fine, Brigadier. You know, you really do look better with that moustache.
Delirious, poor chap.
Doctor, you really ought to rest. You've been unconscious.

Yes, I'm very well aware of that. Oh, the pulse seems to be more or less normal, at a hundred and seventy. Yeah. Yes, both ticking away quite nicely. Although the right one seems a fraction faster. Still that's only to be expected, isn't it?
Doctor, where did you go? Where did the Tardis console take you?

Same time, same place, only a different dimension. It was a parallel world, Liz. Terrible things are happening there. Terrible things. It wasn't this Earth, and yet it was. I didn't go backwards into the past, or forwards into the future. I slipped sideways.
You must lie down.
Brigade Leader, that technician, the one who went berserk and started killing people, have you found him yet?
No.
And Stahlman, how's he?
Still as difficult as ever.
But no worse?
Well, I haven't noticed.
How's the drilling?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Someone knocks at the door.

Dialogue.Line: Just a minute.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Liz opens the door.

Dialogue.Line: Sir Keith!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Gold has his left arm in a sling.

Dialogue.Line: My dear fellow, so you've come back to us after all.
So you're not dead?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: LIZ closes the doors.

Dialogue.Line: No, I came very close to it though.
Why, what happened?
Car crash.
But you're not dead.
You can see he's not dead. The Doctor's been ill, sir.
That's excellent! Excellent!
Well, yes, yes, I think so too. Brigadier, I shall have to lay very serious charges against Professor Stahlman. He ordered my chauffeur to delay my return.
So not everything runs parallel.
He's been ill, you said?
Yes, a coma.
Yes, of course, of course. An infinity of universes, ergo an infinite number of choices. So free will is not an illusion after all. The pattern can be changed.
(into phone) Hello, get me the medical section will you? Thank you.
Now look.
Yes, very well.
Now, wait a minute. I'm not sick, I'm not in need of a doctor and I'm not a raving idiot!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor slams the phone down.

Dialogue.Line: No, no, no, of course not. Perhaps you've had some sort of nightmare.
He did disappear. We saw him.
Sir Keith, unless we do something very, very quickly indeed, there's going to be a disaster.
How do you know, Doctor?
Because I've already seen it.
Professor Stahlman? You must stop this drilling immediately!
Who let this maniac back in here?
Do you hear me? Close down this operation now!
Brigadier, arrest this man.
Now listen to me, all of you! You are not to attempt to penetrate the Earth's crust!
Brigadier, did you hear what I say?
Doctor, please?
Get out of my light! Now stop this drilling!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor attacks a console with a wrench.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!
Stop this drilling! You don't understand, do you?
Benton, get some help, quickly!
You've got stop this drilling!
Now Doctor, calm down!
You see? Completely demented.
Stop this drilling!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Soldiers grab the Doctor's arms.

Dialogue.Line: Take him to the sick bay. Be careful. I don't want him hurt.
No, you can't!
Now Liz, listen to me. Computer. There's a micro circuit missing.
I'll look. Will you treat him carefully?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is hustled away.

Dialogue.Line: Stop it! Stop this drilling!
Brigadier, I hold you responsible.
Professor Stahlman, I'd like to speak to you please.
Ah, Sir Keith. I thought you were supposed to be in London. An accident?
This is a direct consequence of your orders to my chauffeur.
Hmm? Huh! Ridiculous.
Professor, the Minister would like you to report to him immediately, please.
Oh, he would, would he?
There's to be an inquiry into this project and, if I may say so, into your conduct.
You can make as many inquiries as you like, my dear Gold, after we've penetrated the Earth's crust.
Professor Stahlman, I'll be switching to robot controls in forty nine minutes.
Thank you.
Any wrong, Professor?
I feel very cold in here.
Cold?
Yes. Have the maintenance people raise the temperature.
But it's running normally.
Do as I say.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Petra leaves. Stahlman tenses and stares at nothing, whilst hearing something. The technicians stare.

Dialogue.Line: All of you leave this area immediately! Go on! I shall control the last phase of this operation alone. Stand by in the drill head there. Now, go on! Get out, all of you. Go on. Do as I say.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Once alone, he clutches his head in pain.

Dialogue.Line: He's just ordered them all out of there. Now do you believe he's cracked up?
Greg, the heat shield!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The shield slides down to close off the drill head.

Dialogue.Line: Well, I'm sorry about this, gentlemen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor grabs the back of the necks of his two escorts. They collapse, he runs, then heads up a ladder, only to find Green Bromley on the top of the storage tank too. The Doctor grabs a CO2 fire extinguisher and uses it.

Green ooze is coming out of number two output pipe. Stahlman puts his green, hairy hand into it then smears it on his face before falling to the floor growling like an animal. His voice comes over the comms.

Dialogue.Line: Professor Stahlman! Please! What's happening? What's going on in there?
Why don't you raise the heat shield?
Because he's locked it down on manual from the inside.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stahlman now has a full hairy face and fangs.
Liz has mended the computer and is reading the printout.

Dialogue.Line: What does the thing say now?
Zero minus two minutes, fifty seconds.
The Doctor's right. It advises us to stop the drilling at once.
Robot control now operational.
Why don't you give the order, Sir Keith?
Oh, I can't. The order to close down must come from the Professor. I have no authority to intervene.
Zero minus two minutes, forty seconds

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor enters.

Dialogue.Line: Where's Stahlman?
He's locked himself in there!
To final build up.
Good. Then stop this infernal drilling. Well, what are you waiting for?!
Zero minus two minutes, thirty seconds
Stop this drilling and start filling up that shaft!
The data from the computer isn't conclusive, Doctor, nor is Stahlman's behaviour. We have no proof of an emergency situation.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The heat shield rises.

Dialogue.Line: Zero minus two minutes, twenty seconds. Heat control shields now on stand by.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Green Stahlman rushes in.

Dialogue.Line: Zero minus two minutes ten seconds.
Stahlman, get back! Sutton, the fire extinguishers!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As the Doctor turns to get an extinguisher, Green Stahlman raises a chair to hit him. The Brigadier shoots.

Dialogue.Line: Fire extinguishers!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Sutton use the CO2 on Green Stahlman.

Dialogue.Line: Zero minus two minutes, zero seconds and counting. Condition red three now commences.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Green Stahlman collapses.

Dialogue.Line: That's Stahlman?
What's happened to him?
Petra, the drill. Close it down.
Zero minus one minute fifty seconds.
Cut off the nuclear power.
But the drill will disintegrate!
All the better!
Monitoring circuits.
Prepare for emergency shutdown! TECH 1: Section one standing by.
Zero minus one minute TECH 2: Section two standing by. TECH 3: Section three standing by.
Hurry, hurry!
Shut down, now! TECH 1: Section one shut down.
Zero minus one minute, thirty seconds. TECH 2: Section two shut down.
Power build up now completed. TECH 3: Section three shut down. Shut down completed.
But it's still going on!
Zero minus one minute, twenty seconds.
That's the buffer controls at the drill head. Come on!
Non-technical staff to safety positions.
Buffer controls?
Oh, they it slow down by stages. It'll keep going for at least five minutes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A wall panel is open and wires are hanging out.

Dialogue.Line: Zero minus one minute, ten seconds.
The server switches are smashed!
All systems check for final countdown.
Is there anything you can do?
I can only try.
Zero minus one minute, zero seconds and counting. Final countdown commences now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor works on putting the wires back together.

Dialogue.Line: Zero minus
Fifty seconds. Stand by.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Sutton enter.

Dialogue.Line: Attention, attention. Countdown drilling stopped at minus thirty five seconds. All systems closed down.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Liz hugs the Doctor as Petra hugs Sutton.

Dialogue.Line: Sir Keith, I think you'd better give orders for that shaft to be filled in straight away.
Indeed, I will.
I'll send for a stretcher party.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is singing his version of Shine On Harvest Moon.

Dialogue.Line: Shine on Martian moons, up in the sky. Join in. Liz, come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Someone knocks on the door. Liz goes to let them in.

Dialogue.Line: Shine on, shine on, Martian moon.
Sorry to disturb you, Doctor. I just popped in to say goodbye.
Oh, are you leaving, Sir Keith?
Everyone is.
Word came through this morning. This project is being o[fficially abandoned.
Well, I'm not sorry to hear that. What about the nuclear reactor?
They're dismantling it tomorrow.
Oh, but there's time for me to use it just once more, I hope?
Oh, yes, of course, with pleasure. It's the least we can do.
Thank you, Sir Keith. By the way, how's Sutton and Miss Williams?
Oh, they've left already.
Together?
Well, I believe he is driving her to London in his car.
Nothing like a nice happy ending, is there?
No. Well, goodbye, Doctor.
Goodbye, Sir Keith.
Goodbye, Miss Shaw.
Bye bye, Sir Keith.
Goodbye, Brigadier.
Oh, there's quite a lot of mopping up to do. I shall be around for quite a while yet.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Gold leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, pity. Well, come on, Liz. If we've going to link up to that nuclear reactor, we'd better get a move on.
Now, just a moment, Doctor.
Doctor, you're not still tinkering with this machine after all the trouble it's caused us?
The trouble it's caused you?
Doctor, if you hadn't chosen such a crucial moment to disappear, this whole business might have been cleared up a great deal sooner.
Well, he did try to warn everybody, Brigadier.
And a fat lot of notice you all took.
So, you went gallivanting off in a fit of pique.
Brigadier, there are times when you strongly remind me of your other self. I shall leave at once.
In the Tardis console?
Naturally.
Oh, but Doctor, you can't.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor throws the main power breakers.

Dialogue.Line: With the work that we did today, the Tardis console is now fully operational.
We seem to have heard that before.
Goodbye, Liz. I shall miss you, my dear. But I've had about all I can stand of this pompous, self-opinionated idiot here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and the console vanish.

Dialogue.Line: Now see what you've done.
Well, I didn't know he'd go off like that. The man's so infernally touchy.
Well, I shall be most interested to see how you get on without him, Brigadier.
May I remind you, Miss Shaw, that you're still a serving member of UNIT? I don't entirely care for your tone.
I don't much care for yours either. No wonder the Doctor cleared off.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is an cough from the open doorway. There are stains on the Doctor's jacket.

Dialogue.Line: Welcome back.
Where did you go?
A few seconds forward in time, and a few hundred yards due east in space.
The rubbish tip?
The rubbish tip.
Oh, dear.
Er, Brigadier, my dear fellow, I wonder whether I could borrow a couple of your stalwart chaps to give me a hand in bringing the Tardis back? It's landed in rather an inaccessible position.
Pompous, self-opinionated idiot, I believe you said, Doctor?
Yes, well we don't want to bear a grudge for a few hasty words, do we? No, not after all the years that we've worked together. Now come long, my dear fellow, put on a smile. Just remember all

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Liz laughs as the Doctor leads the Brigadier out.
